Tri decenije posle Berlinskog, zidovi i dalje brana protiv globalizacije

04 Nov 2019, 10:05












Berlinski zid je trebalo da bude poslednji, ali i 30 godina posle njegovog pada "Trampov zid" na granici SAD i Meksika, "bezbednosna ograda" izmedju Izraela i Zapadne obale, ograde oko španskih enklava u Maroku i slične strukture još se podižu kao odgovor na izazove globalizacije."Ono za šta su se mnogi nadali da će biti nova era saradnje i otvaranja granica označio je 9. novembar 1989. Čini se, da se 30 godina kasnije, desilo potpuno suprotno: svet na probleme medjunarodne bezbednosti odgovara zidovima, militarizacijom i izolacijom", naveo je Transnacionalni institut (TNI), holandska nevladina organizacija.Naučnica iz njujorškog Insituta za medjunarodni mir Aleksandra Novoselof navela je da je "talas optimizma bio kratkotrajan"."Zidovi su uvek tu i broj im raste. Danas ih je više nego pre 30 godina. Izbrojala sam ih 20, duplo više nego 1989", rekla je ona.Prema navodima politikologa Elizabet Valet, danas je "izgradjeno ili najavljeno 70 do 75 zidova", u odnosu 1989. godinu kada ih je bilo oko 15.Postojeći zidovi imaju ukupnu dužinu od oko 40.000 kilometara, što je jednako obimu planete.Iako je globalizacija donela nadu u nestanak granica, takodje je izazvala i "povratni udar", hraneći "suverenizam i nacionalizam koji vole ograde", rekao je Bruno Tertre, jedan od autora knjige "Atlas granica. Zidovi, sukobi, migracije" i vršilac dužnosti direktora pariskog Fonda za strateška istraživanja.Prema Tertreu, posle terorističkih napada na Njujork i Vašington 11. septembra 2001. "ograde su se umnogostručile".Aleksandra Novoselof kaže da su zidovi gradjeni da bi se "na neki pomalo smešan način borilo protiv globalnih fenomena poput terorizma, migracija ili siromaštva".Prema rečima francuskog naučnika Mišela Fušea, u društvu koje je izgubilo orijentaciju od države se traži snažna zaštita a "prostorna granica se doživljava kao apsolutna zaštita". Zid je, prema tome, "metafora koja treba da pokrije svaki nemir"."U eri brzog napredovanja populizma zid je brzo rešenje koje populističke vlade mogu brzo da iskoriste", kaže Elizabet Valet.Bezbednosne ograde i zidovi su u današnje vreme sve više usmereni protiv migracija."Države članice Evropske unije i šengenskog prostora su od devedesetih godina izgradile skoro 1.000 kilometara zidova, što je šest puta duže od Berlinskog zida, da bi sprečile ulazak raseljenog stanovništva", navodi se u izveštaju holandskog TNI.Valet ipak navodi da zidovi ne sprečavaju protok ljudi."Umesto toga, oni migracije guraju u podzemlje. Oni ne sprečavaju šverc, većina droge koja ulazi u SAD ulazi preko carinskih punktova. Takodje, zidovi sakrivaju stvarnost sve veće nesigurnosti globalnog juga. Kada milioni ljudi ne budu imali drugi izbor do da odu, zidovi više ničemu neće služiti", rekla je ona.S druge strane, neki upozoravaju na "demonizaciju zidova"."Zidovi nisu rešenje nego hitni odgovori na hitne probleme", kaže francuski istoričar Klod Ketel.Američki naučnik Majkl Rubin, sa svoje strane, upozorava da je važno praviti razliku izmedju današnjih graničnih zidova čija namena je kontrola ulaska u neku zemlju i nekadašnjeg Berlinskog zida koji je branio da se iz zemlje izadje."Zidovi funkcionišu ako im je cilj da zaštite nacionalnu bezbednost i uguše ilegalnu imigraciju", rekao je Rubin, i kao primer toga izneo izraelsku ogradu na granici s okupiranom Zapadnom obalom. Prema njegovim rečima, gotovo odmah po podizanju ograde broj terorističkih napada u Izraelu je smanjen za 90 odsto.
text:
Three decades after Berlin, the walls are still a bulwark against globalization

04 Nov 2019, 09:05












The Berlin Wall was supposed to be the last, but 30 years after its fall, the Trump Wall at the US-Mexico border, a "security fence" between Israel and the West Bank, fences around Spanish enclaves in Morocco and similar structures are still being erected in response to the challenges of globalization. "What many hoped would be a new era of co-operation and the opening of borders marked November 9, 1989. It seems that 30 years later, the opposite has happened: the world is responding to the problems of international security by walls, militarization and isolation, "said the Transnational Institute (TNI), a Dutch non-governmental organization. A scholar at the New York Institute for International Peace, Alexander Novoselof, stated that" the wave of optimism was short-lived. "" The walls are always there and their numbers are growing. 30 years ago. I counted 20 of them, double the number in 1989, "she said. According to political scientist Elizabeth Vallet, today, 70 to 75 walls have been constructed or announced," compared to 1989. when there were about 15.The existing walls have a total length of about 40,000 kilometers, which is equal to the size of the planet. said Bruno Tertre, one of the authors of the book Atlas of Borders. Walls, Conflicts, Migration "and Acting Director of the Paris Strategic Research Fund. According to Tertre, after the terrorist attacks on New York and Washington on September 11, 2001," fences have multiplied ". Alexandra Novoselof says the walls were built to" a somewhat ridiculous way of combating global phenomena such as terrorism, migration or poverty. "According to French scientist Michel Fouche, a society that has lost its orientation requires strong protection and a" spatial border is perceived as absolute protection. " "The metaphor that should cover any unrest." "In an era of rapid advancement of populism, the wall is a quick solution that populist governments can quickly exploit," says Elizabeth Vallet. Security fences and walls are increasingly directed against migration today. Member States of the European Union and the Schengen area have built nearly 1,000 kilometers of walls since the 1990s, which is six times longer from the Berlin Wall, to prevent displaced people from entering, "according to a report from the Dutch TNI.Vallet still states that the walls do not prevent the flow of people." Instead, they push migration underground. They do not prevent smuggling, most drugs entering the US enter via customs points. Also, the walls hide the reality of the growing uncertainty of the global south. When millions of people have no choice but to leave, the walls will no longer serve anything, "she said. On the other hand, some warn of" demonizing the walls. "" Walls are not the solution but urgent responses to urgent problems, "says the French historian Claude Kettel.American scientist Michael Rubin, for his part, warns that it is important to distinguish between today's border walls, which are intended to control entry into a country and the former Berlin Wall, which defended the exit of the country. " to protect national security and suppress illegal immigration, "Rubin said, citing the Israeli fence on the occupied West Bank border as an example. According to him, almost immediately after raising the fence, the number of terrorist attacks in Israel was reduced by 90 percent.
